page.title: 02CULMSTOCK BEACON
page.content: The south-west point of BLACKDOWN COMMON is called CULMSTOCK BEACON, on which stands a unique BEEHIVE BEACON HUT said to date from Armada times, if not earlier. This Beacon Hut was used for lighting fires as a warning of advancing enemies, for example, 'The Spanish Armada' and was one in a chain of fire signals. Nowadays, fires are lit in the Hut in celebration, such as the ending of the War and the Queen's Silver Jubilee in 1977. About 50 acres of land on Culmstock Beacon have been given to the people of Culmstock, in perpetuity, for their enjoyment and recreation. Lying in an area designated as one of outstanding natural beauty, there is an abundance of flora to enjoy - the Beacon clad in bell-heather and ling is a sight to remember! Signs of flint stone quarrying can still be seen.
